Recording volume was boosted by 6db in audacity. I clipped the sections with handling noise at the beginning and end of the recording, intervals between vocalizations were not modified. Recorded on a Zoom H4N (set to record WAV 96kHz/24bit) with a deadcat.  Bird was singing in a roadside shrub (about two meters off the ground) next to a cornfield. Tan streaky sparrow with a pale eyering, malar, and rufous lesser coverts. Conditions were sunny (no cloud cover) and about 10°C with low winds.

This is almost certainly the SAME individual in XC482287 recorded the previous day from the SAME perch. The song elements used are very nearly identical and given in the same order. Since there seems to be little sharing of song elements between nearby birds, AND given the same perch, this seems highly likely to be the same bird.

This is almost certainly the SAME individual in XC482289 recorded the following day from the SAME perch. The song elements used are very nearly identical and given in the same order. Since there seems to be little sharing of song elements between nearby birds, AND given the same perch, this seems highly likely to be the same bird.

recordings.loc: Snow Mountain Ranch, Yakima County, Washington
recordings.rmk: Singing on a small sage brush 30 meters away. Weather: hot, partly cloudy. Habitat: open sage-and-wildflower-speckled hilltop. Slight HPF used.
A Vesper Sparrow singing from a trailside shrub in the prairie.

So, this is the bird I have named Hopeful. He's been hanging out in this location for several years now, and as far as I have seen, he's the only Vesper Sparrow here. He's constantly surrounded instead by Savannah Sparrows, and I believe he has picked up some song elements from them over the years, and so he now sounds like this. Yes, he is a Vesper Sparrow. Well-documented by me and many others, photographed, etc. His song is just very strange. Hopeful has a specific territory in the mounds (accurate to the meter when we relocate him) that he returns to each year, and he sings his little heart out in it. (Male is assumed, since male and female Vespers are similar.) When singing, he goes to a prominent perch over the tallest grasses (small scrub brush, short deciduous tree seedlings, fenceposts, etc.) much like the Savannah Sparrows. He doesn't seem to associate with the Savannahs, and we have seen them in conflict before. Weather: cool (around 60 degrees F), mostly cloudy (but still bright), occasional winds but usually calm with gentle or no breeze. Light amplification, and high pass filter used to cut out worst of wind noise.
Bird perched  on a barbed wire  fence located just off the road in a grassy meadow.

recordings.loc: Grey Cloud Dunes SNA, Washington, Minnesota
recordings.rmk:
Two birds in a small wooded area in the middle of sandy prairie. Both birds were singing and always close together.  One would fly to a perch in a tree and the other would follow, then one would fly down to a small bush near the ground and the other would follow, etc. They frequently chased eachother through the bushes.  At regular intervals, they would take fluttery flights together in a loop out over the prairie  and then come back to the same area and resume singing.  Individual #4 and #5 recorded today.

Recorded with homemade parabolic reflector and Sony PCM-M10. Sunny and cool.

recordings.loc: Lower Moreland (near  Huntingdon Valley), Montgomery, Pennsylvania
recordings.rmk: migrant, singing high in tree

This recording is a segment of a 10-minute long recording made by an automated digital recorder.  No one was present at the time this recording was made and therefore the bird was not seen.  The site is an upland forest about 50-60 years old composed mainly of Jack Pine (Pinus banksiana) and Black Spruce (Picea mariana).  The bird in questions is the first and last vocalization in the recording but it also sings a number of times throughout.  My instinct is this is a Field Sparrow (Spizella pusilla) but the site location is significantly (?) out of it's range.  I would appreciate hearing other opinons on what bird this might be.

recordings.rmk: Sparrow singing from across corn field. There were a couple of song sparrows singing. But this one sounded different. Thought it was Vesper in the field. Less sure now that I am comparing sonograms? Vesper Sparrow is one of those birds I have trouble with. Its song seems to dissapear into the background and get lost in amongst all the song sparrows. Sorry for poor recording. Distance was significant.
